awd_titl_txt: Biased Beliefs and Search in Education Markets
awd_abstract_narration:
Choosing the right school for one?s child may determine the child?s future educational outcomes, yet parents do not always choose the best schools because of inadequate information.  This research will use experimental methods to study the reasons parents make school choices with very little information about options available to them.  The research will study the relative importance of two mechanisms through which this occurs: (i) difficulty and cost of acquiring information about school characteristics, and/or (ii) families have incorrect beliefs about the distribution of schools, believing that all schools are the same.  Each of these mechanisms has a different policy implication.  The research will develop a theoretical model based on parent?s beliefs about school quality and how these beliefs change as they receive new information.  The research will then test this theory by providing different amounts of information to parents to see how this affects their school choice decisions.  Comparing outcomes for parents who receive information to those of parents who do not receive information allows the researchers to determine the effects of information and its costs on parental school choice.  The results of this study will provide a better understanding of why parents do not always choose the best schools as well as provide inputs into policies to improve parental school choice.  The results will also help improve school and education policies, increase human capital formation, and ultimately economic growth. 
 
This proposed research will examine why parents may not choose the best schools for their children by investigating the process of information acquisition to make school choices.  The researchers will develop a structural model of sequential search which allows for biased beliefs about school characteristics, search costs, and the benefits of search.   The researchers will test this model using data collected from a randomized control trial (RCT).  The experimental results will then be used to estimate the structural model on parental educational choice using merged data from the experiment and administrative data on school characteristics, family characteristics, cost of information acquisition, and school outcomes.  The results of this research will provide important inputs into parental education decisions, improve educational outcomes and ultimately increase the stock of human capital and economic growth in the US.  The results will also establish the US as a global leader in research on parental school decisions.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Many families, especially the most disadvantaged, make important school choices with very little information about their options and it has been shown that this contributes to educational inequality. While these patterns have been attributed to high costs of acquiring information, we propose an additional channel that leads families' to make less effort searching and acquiring information: parents underestimate the number of affordable high-quality schools in their neighborhood, making them underinvest in search.

To study this channel, our research team worked with the Ministry of Education in the Dominican Republic to implement two randomized information interventions with parents in Santo Domingo in 2023. We embedded our intervention as a welcome module on a digital platform that provides general information about schools. We first elicited beliefs about the schools available nearby and their price and quality. The intervention then provided individualized information on the true number and distribution of attributes of available schools and we tracked parents' subsequent search behavior on the platform. We contrast this search behavior with i) the behavior of families that are provided direct recommendations about specific schools and with ii) the search behavior of a control group of families that did not get any additional information but did have access to the search platform. 

Consistent with our initial hypotheses, we show that parents have incorrect beliefs about the distribution of schools in their neighborhood and that this leads them to underinvest in search. Using baseline information, we first document that parents underestimate the number of affordable high-quality schools in their neighborhood. We then show that an intervention that corrects these beliefs encourages parents to search more: treatment group parents click on 62% more schools within the search platform than their control group counterparts. Treatment effects on enrollment outcomes are noisy, but we find suggestive evidence that the treatment increases the likelihood that parents enroll their children in more affordable schools.

These results are important because they suggest new ways to design information provision policies. Instead of predicting what families would like, and providing specific recommendations, a complementary policy could focus on the deeper friction that limits families' own search and discovery. In addition, these results also suggest that even as digital platforms that aggregate information become more common, this alone will not necessarily reduce the inequality in awareness and understanding about access to education. 

We have replicated the intervention and found similar results. Using the insights from our fieldwork in the Dominican Republic, we implemented follow-up studies in which we replicated the information interventions within the centralized school choice system in Chile. As in the Dominican Republic, we find in Chile that correcting parental beliefs about the aggregate distribution of schools affects search effort and school enrollment. Using the larger sample and the more detailed survey information in Chile, we wrote a scientific paper titled “Search and Biased Beliefs in Education Markets” that we have presented at several academic venues including the NBER market design working group meeting in fall 2023, and we are currently preparing for submission to a top academic journal.
